awd_titl_txt: Research Experience In Tissue Engineering Science and Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will enable the Principal Investigator (PI) to support a Tissue Engineering Science and Technology summer school project for underrepresented minorities students in STEM. The summer school is designed to create a class room environment aimed to provide participants with hands-on research experience and focused training and mentoring for underrepresented minority/women students in the emerging field of tissue engineering. The hierarchy-based learning environment involves the principle investigator, graduate students and undergraduates along with new recruits to develop strategies to design biomaterial structures, create tissues and tissue interfaces. During the summer, the participants will implement new designs and strategies to build their engineered tissue. 

The project will focus on promoting diversity in engineering, science and technology and will use a mentorship approach that involves providing research experience as well as mentoring participants in professional development, scientific writing, and communications skills development. Participants of this project will bring new knowledge and demos of prototypes to the classroom that will serve as a tool to create awareness in science and engineering technologies. The immediate benefits would include promotion of STEM careers and address long-term workforce diversity issues in the biomedical science/ engineering related areas. This award will allow the PI to implement a successful mentoring program and create laboratory mentoring demonstrations to attract minority/women students in STEM careers. The PI has both a successful track record and the resources necessary to successfully implement this highly rewarding education grant.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Office of Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI)

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this training was to introduce tissue engineering science and technology research at early stage to biomedical engineering undergraduate students. Additionally, this year's program was focused on teaching design development, choosing optimal design and developing the optimal design into a product. 

A total of seventeen students received training and mentorshuip under this program in various topics of Biomaterials, science, technology and design projects. The participants also received mentorship training on a number of aspects including how to read a journal article and what is research hypothesis.

Majority of the participants received training in engineering design. Participants designed and implemented several aspects of engineering design including design development, choosing optimal design and developing the optimal design into a product. This training helped the participants to come up with prototype designs and these are presented in the annual engineering design day event.

The research activities carried out under this program resulted in three journal and two conference publications. All the participants who have gone through the program appreciate what is research and how to come up with a problem and design experiments to address the research question asked.

Overall, this program trained seventeen women and underrepresented minority students in biomaterials research. Several of them are interested to continue their careers in STEM areas, in particular in the biomaterials field. Therefore, the program has been completed as outlined and the achivements clearly demonstrate the success of this program.


Last Modified: 07/30/2022
Modified by: Syam P Nukavarapu
